column2: The only times, said he, "that me and Andy Tucker ever had any hiatuses in our cordial intents was when we differed on the moral aspects of grafting.
column3: The only times, said he, "that me and Andy Tucker ever had any hiatuses in our cordial intents was when we differed on the moral aspects of grafting.

column2: Andy had his standards and I had mine.
column3: Andy had his standards and I had mine.

column2: I didn't approve of all of Andy's schemes for levying contributions from the public, and he thought I allowed my conscience to interfere too often for the financial good of the firm.
column3: I didn't approve of all of Andy's schemes for levying contributions from the public, and he thought I allowed my conscience to interfere too often for the financial good of the firm.

column2: We had high arguments sometimes. One word led on to another till he said I reminded him of Rockefeller.
column3: We had high arguments sometimes. One word led on to another till he said I reminded him of Rockefeller.

column2: 'I don't know how you mean that, Andy,' says I, 'but we have been friends too long for me to take offense at a taunt that you will regret when you cool off.	'I don't know how you mean that, Andy,' says I, 'but we have been friends too long for me to take offense at a taunt that you will regret when you cool off.
column3: true

column2: I have yet,' says I, 'to shake hands with a subpoena server.'
column3: I have yet,' says I, 'to shake hands with a subpoena server.'

column2: One summer me and Andy decided to rest up a spell in a fine little town in the mountains of Kentucky called Grassdale.	One summer me and Andy decided to rest up a spell in a fine little town in the mountains of Kentucky called Grassdale.
column3: true

column2: We was supposed to be horse drovers, and good decent citizens besides, taking a summer vacation.
column3: We was supposed to be horse drovers, and good decent citizens besides, taking a summer vacation.

column2: The Grassdale people liked us, and me and Andy declared a cessation of hostilities, never so much as floating the fly leaf of a rubber concession prospectus or flashing a Brazilian diamond while we was there.
column3: The Grassdale people liked us, and me and Andy declared a cessation of hostilities, never so much as floating the fly leaf of a rubber concession prospectus or flashing a Brazilian diamond while we was there.

column2: One day the leading hardware merchant of Grassdale drops around to the hotel where me and Andy stopped, and smokes with us, sociable, on the side porch.	One day the leading hardware merchant of Grassdale drops around to the hotel where me and Andy stopped, and smokes with us, sociable, on the side porch.
column3: true

column2: We knew him pretty well from pitching quoits in the afternoons in the court house yard.
column3: We knew him pretty well from pitching quoits in the afternoons in the court house yard.

column2: He was a loud, red man, breathing hard, but fat and respectable beyond all reason.
column3: He was a loud, red man, breathing hard, but fat and respectable beyond all reason.

column2: [Illustration: "Pitching quoits in the afternoon in the court house yard."]
column3: [Illustration: "Pitching quoits in the afternoon in the court house yard."]

column2: After we talk on all the notorious themes of the day, this Murkison-- for such was his entitlements--takes a letter out of his coat pocket in a careful, careless way and hands it to us to read. column2: 'Now, what do you think of that?' says he, laughing--'a letter like that to ME!'	'Now, what do you think of that?' says he, laughing-'a letter like that to m e!'

column2: Me and Andy sees at a glance what it is; but we pretend to read it through.	Me and Andy sees at a glance what it is; but we pretend to read it through.
column3: false

column2: It was one of them old time typewritten green goods letters explaining how for $1,000 you could get $5,000 in bills that an expert couldn't tell from the genuine; and going on to tell how they were made from plates stolen by an employee of the Treasury at Washington.
column3: It was one of them old time typewritten green goods letters explaining how for one thousand dollars you could get five thousand dollars in bills that an expert couldn't tell from the genuine; and going on to tell how they were made from plates stolen by an employee of the Treasury at Washington.

column2: 'Think of 'em sending a letter like that to ME!' says Murkison again.	'Think of 'em sending a letter like that to m e!' says Murkison again.

column2: 'If you don't answer the first letter they let you drop.
column3: 'If you don't answer the first letter they let you drop.

column2: If you answer it they write again asking you to come on with your money and do business.'
column3: If you answer it they write again asking you to come on with your money and do business.'

column2: 'But think of 'em writing to ME!' says Murkison.	'But think of 'em writing to m e!' says Murkison.

column2: 'Boys,' says he, 'I know you are all right or I wouldn't confide in you.	'Boys,' says he, 'I know you are all right or I wouldn't confide in you.

column2: I wrote to them rascals again just for fun.
column3: I wrote to them rascals again just for fun.

column2: They answered and told me to come on to Chicago.
column3: They answered and told me to come on to Chicago.

column2: They said telegraph to J. Smith when I would start.
column3: They said telegraph to j Smith when I would start.

column2: When I get there I'm to wait on a certain street corner till a man in a gray suit comes along and drops a newspaper in front of me.
column3: When I get there I'm to wait on a certain street corner till a man in a gray suit comes along and drops a newspaper in front of me.

column2: Then I am to ask him how the water is, and he knows it's me and I know it's him.'
column3: Then I am to ask him how the water is, and he knows it's me and I know it's him.'

column2: 'Ah, yes,' says Andy, gaping, 'it's the same old game.	'Ah, yes,' says Andy, gaping, 'it's the same old game.

column2: I've often read about it in the papers.
column3: I've often read about it in the papers.

column2: Then he conducts you to the private abattoir in the hotel, where Mr. Jones is already waiting.
column3: Then he conducts you to the private abattoir in the hotel, where mr Jones is already waiting.

column2: They show you brand new real money and sell you all you want at five for one. You see 'em put it in a satchel for you and know it's there.
column3: They show you brand new real money and sell you all you want at five for one. You see 'em put it in a satchel for you and know it's there.

column2: Of course it's brown paper when you come to look at it afterward.'
column3: Of course it's brown paper when you come to look at it afterward.'

column3: [Illustration: "'Of course, it's brown paper.'"]

column2: 'Oh, they couldn't switch it on me,' says Murkison. 'I haven't built up the best paying business in Grassdale without having witticisms about me. column2: You say it's real money they show you, Mr. Tucker?'
column3: You say it's real money they show you, mr Tucker?'

column2: 'I've always--I see by the papers that it always is,' says Andy.	'I've always-I see by the papers that it always is,' says Andy.
column3: true

column2: I think I'll put a couple of thousand in my jeans and go up there and put it all over 'em.
column3: I think I'll put a couple of thousand in my jeans and go up there and put it all over 'em.

column2: If Bill Murkison gets his eyes once on them bills they show him he'll never take 'em off of 'em.
column3: If Bill Murkison gets his eyes once on them bills they show him he'll never take 'em off of 'em.

column2: They offer $5 for $1, and they'll have to stick to the bargain if I tackle 'em.
column3: They offer five dollars for one dollar, and they'll have to stick to the bargain if I tackle 'em.

column2: That's the kind of trader Bill Murkison is.
column3: That's the kind of trader Bill Murkison is.

column2: Yes, I jist believe I'll drop up Chicago way and take a 5 to 1 shot on J. Smith.
column3: Yes, I jist believe I'll drop up Chicago way and take a five to one shot on j Smith.

column2: I guess the water'll be fine enough.'
column3: I guess the water'll be fine enough.'

column2: Me and Andy tries to get this financial misquotation out of Murkison's head, but we might as well have tried to keep the man who rolls peanuts with a toothpick from betting on Bryan's election. column2: Maybe it would teach 'em a lesson.
column3: Maybe it would teach 'em a lesson.

column2: After Murkison left us me and Andy sat a while prepondering over our silent meditations and heresies of reason.	After Murkison left us me and Andy sat a while prepondering over our silent meditations and heresies of reason.

column3: In our idle hours we always improved our higher selves by ratiocination and mental thought.

column2: 'Jeff,' says Andy after a long time, 'quite unseldom I have seen fit to impugn your molars when you have been chewing the rag with me about your conscientious way of doing business. column2: I may have been often wrong. But here is a case where I think we can agree.
column3: I may have been often wrong. But here is a case where I think we can agree.

column2: I feel that it would be wrong for us to allow Mr. Murkison to go alone to meet those Chicago green goods men.
column3: I feel that it would be wrong for us to allow mr Murkison to go alone to meet those Chicago green goods men.

column2: There is but one way it can end.
column3: There is but one way it can end.

column2: Don't you think we would both feel better if we was to intervene in some way and prevent the doing of this deed?'
column3: Don't you think we would both feel better if we was to intervene in some way and prevent the doing of this deed?'

column2: I got up and shook Andy Tucker's hand hard and long.	I got up and shook Andy Tucker's hand hard and long.
column3: true

column2: 'Andy,' says I, 'I may have had one or two hard thoughts about the heartlessness of your corporation, but I retract 'em now.	'Andy,' says I, 'I may have had one or two hard thoughts about the heartlessness of your corporation, but I retract 'em now.
column3: true

column2: You have a kind nucleus at the interior of your exterior after all.
column3: You have a kind nucleus at the interior of your exterior after all.

column2: It does you credit.
column3: It does you credit.

column2: I was just thinking the same thing that you have expressed. It would not be honorable or praiseworthy,' says I, 'for us to let Murkison go on with this project he has taken up.
column3: I was just thinking the same thing that you have expressed. It would not be honorable or praiseworthy,' says I, 'for us to let Murkison go on with this project he has taken up.

column2: If he is determined to go let us go with him and prevent this swindle from coming off.'
column3: If he is determined to go let us go with him and prevent this swindle from coming off.'

column2: Andy agreed with me; and I was glad to see that he was in earnest about breaking up this green goods scheme.	Andy agreed with me; and I was glad to see that he was in earnest about breaking up this green goods scheme.

column2: 'I don't call myself a religious man,' says I, 'or a fanatic in moral bigotry, but I can't stand still and see a man who has built up his business by his own efforts and brains and risk be robbed by an unscrupulous trickster who is a menace to the public good.'	'I don't call myself a religious man,' says I, 'or a fanatic in moral bigotry, but I can't stand still and see a man who has built up his business by his own efforts and brains and risk be robbed by an unscrupulous trickster who is a menace to the public good.'

column3: true

column2: I'd hate to see any money dropped in it as bad as you would.'
column3: I'd hate to see any money dropped in it as bad as you would.'

column2: Well, we went to see Murkison.	Well, we went to see Murkison.

column2: 'No, boys,' says he.	'No, boys,' says he.

column2: 'I can't consent to let the song of this Chicago siren waft by me on the summer breeze.
column3: 'I can't consent to let the song of this Chicago siren waft by me on the summer breeze.

column2: I'll fry some fat out of this ignis fatuus or burn a hole in the skillet.
column3: I'll fry some fat out of this ignis fatuus or burn a hole in the skillet.

column2: But I'd be plumb diverted to death to have you all go along with me.
column3: But I'd be plumb diverted to death to have you all go along with me.

column2: Maybe you could help some when it comes to cashing in the ticket to that 5 to 1 shot.
column3: Maybe you could help some when it comes to cashing in the ticket to that five to one shot.

column2: Yes, I'd really take it as a pastime and regalement if you boys would go along too.'
column3: Yes, I'd really take it as a pastime and regalement if you boys would go along too.'

column2: Oh, my, my, my!' And then he laughs all over for five minutes.

column2: It would ruin me there.

column2: But I know you all are all right.
column3: But I know you all are all right.

column2: I'll show 'em whether the water's fine.

column2: Five dollars for one--that's what J. Smith offers, and he'll have to keep his contract if he does business with Bill Murkison.'
column3: Five dollars for one-that's what j Smith offers, and he'll have to keep his contract if he does business with Bill Murkison.'

column2: We got into Chicago about 7 P.M.	We got into Chicago about seven p m

column2: Murkison was to meet the gray man at half past 9.
column3: Murkison was to meet the gray man at half past nine.

column2: We had dinner at a hotel and then went up to Murkison's room to wait for the time to come.
column3: We had dinner at a hotel and then went up to Murkison's room to wait for the time to come.

column3: Suppose while I'm exchanging airy bandage with the gray capper you gents come along, by accident, you know, and holler: "Hello, Murk!" and shake hands with symptoms of surprise and familiarity.

column2: Then I take the capper aside and tell him you all are Jenkins and Brown of Grassdale, groceries and feed, good men and maybe willing to take a chance while away from home.'
column3: Then I take the capper aside and tell him you all are Jenkins and Brown of Grassdale, groceries and feed, good men and maybe willing to take a chance while away from home.'

column2: 'Bring 'em along," he'll say, of course, "if they care to invest." Now, how does that scheme strike you?'
column3: 'Bring 'em along," he'll say, of course, "if they care to invest." Now, how does that scheme strike you?'

column2: 'What do you say, Jeff?' says Andy, looking at me.	'What do you say, Jeff?' says Andy, looking at me.

column2: I don't see any use of wasting any more time.' I took a nickel-plated .38 out of my pocket and clicked the cylinder around a few times.
column3: I don't see any use of wasting any more time.' I took a nickel plated point three eight out of my pocket and clicked the cylinder around a few times.

column2: 'You undevout, sinful, insidious hog,' says I to Murkison, 'get out that two thousand and lay it on the table.	'You undevout, sinful, insidious hog,' says I to Murkison, 'get out that two thousand and lay it on the table.

column2: Obey with velocity,' says I, 'for otherwise alternatives are impending.
column3: Obey with velocity,' says I, 'for otherwise alternatives are impending.

column2: I am preferably a man of mildness, but now and then I find myself in the middle of extremities. Such men as you,' I went on after he had laid the money out, 'is what keeps the jails and court houses going.
column3: I am preferably a man of mildness, but now and then I find myself in the middle of extremities. Such men as you,' I went on after he had laid the money out, 'is what keeps the jails and court houses going.

column2: You come up here to rob these men of their money.
column3: You come up here to rob these men of their money.

column2: Does it excuse you?' I asks, 'that they were trying to skin you?
column3: Does it excuse you?' I asks, 'that they were trying to skin you?

column2: No, sir; you was going to rob Peter to stand off Paul.
column3: No, sir; you was going to rob peter to stand off Paul.

column2: You are ten times worse,' says I, 'than that green goods man. You go to church at home and pretend to be a decent citizen, but you'll come to Chicago and commit larceny from men that have built up a sound and profitable business by dealing with such contemptible scoundrels as you have tried to be to-day.
column3: You are ten times worse,' says I, 'than that green goods man. You go to church at home and pretend to be a decent citizen, but you'll come to Chicago and commit larceny from men that have built up a sound and profitable business by dealing with such contemptible scoundrels as you have tried to be to day.

column2: How do you know,' says I, 'that that green goods man hasn't a large family dependent upon his extortions?
column3: How do you know,' says I, 'that that green goods man hasn't a large family dependent upon his extortions?

column2: It's you supposedly respectable citizens who are always on the lookout to get something for nothing,' says I, 'that support the lotteries and wild-cat mines and stock exchanges and wire tappers of this country.
column3: It's you supposedly respectable citizens who are always on the lookout to get something for nothing,' says I, 'that support the lotteries and wild cat mines and stock exchanges and wire tappers of this country.

column2: If it wasn't for you they'd go out of business. The green goods man you was going to rob,' says I, 'studied maybe for years to learn his trade.
column3: If it wasn't for you they'd go out of business. The green goods man you was going to rob,' says I, 'studied maybe for years to learn his trade.

column2: Every turn he makes he risks his money and liberty and maybe his life.
column3: Every turn he makes he risks his money and liberty and maybe his life.

column2: You come up here all sanctified and vanoplied with respectability and a pleasing post office address to swindle him.
column3: You come up here all sanctified and vanoplied with respectability and a pleasing post office address to swindle him.

column2: If he gets the money you can squeal to the police.
column3: If he gets the money you can squeal to the police.

column2: If you get it he hocks the gray suit to buy supper and says nothing.
column3: If you get it he hocks the gray suit to buy supper and says nothing.

column2: Mr. Tucker and me sized you up,' says I, 'and came along to see that you got what you deserved.
column3: mr Tucker and me sized you up,' says I, 'and came along to see that you got what you deserved.

column2: Hand over the money,' says I, 'you grass fed hypocrite.'
column3: Hand over the money,' says I, 'you grass fed hypocrite.'

column3: true

column2: Then you can go.
column3: Then you can go.

column2: If you make any noise or leave any sooner we'll handbill you all over Grassdale.
column3: If you make any noise or leave any sooner we'll handbill you all over Grassdale.

column2: I guess your high position there is worth more than $2,000 to you.'
column3: I guess your high position there is worth more than two thousand dollars to you.'
